content.definition: The Abducens Nerve (CN VI) is a somatic motor cranial nerve originating from the pontomedullary junction that exclusively innervates the [[f7b5ee5d|Lateral Rectus muscle]], enabling horizontal eye abduction (looking laterally away from the nose).
content.atAGlance:
• Function: Motor innervation to the ipsilateral lateral rectus muscle (abduction).
  • Pathway: Exits brainstem at pontomedullary junction → cavernous sinus → superior orbital fissure.
  • Lesion Presentation: Medial strabismus (eye turns inward) and horizontal [[9914d433|diplopia]] that worsens when looking toward the affected side.
  • Clinical Association: Highly susceptible to downward traction from increased intracranial pressure due to its long intracranial course.
  • USMLE Tip: An isolated CN VI palsy is often a "false localizing sign" of elevated ICP (e.g., pseudotumor cerebri) rather than a direct brainstem lesion.
content.takeAway: The Abducens Nerve has the longest subarachnoid course of all cranial nerves, making it uniquely vulnerable to stretching from increased intracranial pressure, often presenting as a nonlocalizing palsy unrelated to direct trauma.

content.definition: Alzheimer Disease is the most common neurodegenerative cause of dementia in older adults, characterized by the extracellular accumulation of amyloid-beta (Aβ) plaques and intracellular accumulation of hyperphosphorylated tau tangles, leading to widespread cortical atrophy and cholinergic deficit.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Accumulation of Senile plaques (Aβ from Amyloid Precursor Protein) and Neurofibrillary tangles (hyperphosphorylated tau).
  • Genetics: Early onset associated with APP (Chr 21), Presenilin-1 (Chr 14), Presenilin-2 (Chr 1). Late onset risk increased by ApoE4 allele (Chr 19).
  • Clinical: Insidious, progressive memory loss, visuospatial deficits, and personality changes.
  • Neurotransmitters: Significant decrease in [[6a005559|Acetylcholine]] levels in the [[361438f2|Basal nucleus of Meynert]].
  • USMLE Tip: Patients with Down syndrome (Trisomy 21) have an increased risk of early-onset Alzheimer's because the APP gene is located on Chromosome 21 (gene dosage effect).
content.takeAway: The hallmark pathology of Alzheimer Disease involves extracellular amyloid plaques and intracellular tau tangles, which precipitate a decline in cholinergic signaling, making [[0835ea01|AChE inhibitors]] (like [[47d0372e|Donepezil]]) the mainstay of symptomatic treatment.

content.definition: The Dorsal Columns are ascending spinal cord tracts composed of the fasciculus gracilis and fasciculus cuneatus that transmit fine touch, vibration, and conscious proprioception from the peripheral nerves to the brainstem nuclei.
content.atAGlance:
• Organization: Fasciculus Gracilis (medial, lower body/legs), Fasciculus Cuneatus (lateral, upper body/arms) [Mnemonic: Gracilis = Ground, Cuneatus = Ceiling].
  • Pathway: First-order neurons ascend ipsilaterally → synapse in medulla → decussate as internal arcuate fibers → ascend as [[f19bc454|Medial Lemniscus]].
  • Clinical Signs: Loss of vibration/proprioception, positive [[47a0f3d1|Romberg sign]], sensory ataxia.
  • Associated Pathologies: Damaged in [[71daebd6|Tabes Dorsalis]] (syphilis) and [[6f5bea90|Subacute Combined Degeneration]] (B12 deficiency).
  • USMLE Tip: Remember that dorsal column lesions cause ipsilateral deficits below the lesion because decussation occurs in the medulla, not the spinal cord.
content.takeAway: The Dorsal Columns are unique among sensory tracts because they ascend ipsilaterally within the spinal cord and only decussate in the lower medulla to form the medial lemniscus; thus, spinal cord hemisections (Brown-SÃ©quard) result in ipsilateral loss of vibration and proprioception.

content.definition: Tabes Dorsalis is a late-stage neurosyphilis manifestation characterized by the demyelination and degeneration of the dorsal columns and dorsal roots of the spinal cord, leading to progressive sensory ataxia and loss of reflexes.
content.atAGlance:
• Pathophysiology: Caused by Treponema pallidum (Tertiary Syphilis) destroying the [[e7f5cbbe|Dorsal Columns]].
  • Clinical Triad: Sensory ataxia (wide-based gait), sharp/shooting pains ("lightning pains"), and [[08cb577f|Argyll Robertson pupils]].
  • Physical Exam: Positive [[47a0f3d1|Romberg sign]], absent DTRs (areflexia), and impaired vibration/proprioception.
  • Complications: [[cfbd9f68|Charcot joints]] (neuropathic arthropathy) due to loss of pain sensation.
  • USMLE Tip: Look for the Argyll Robertson pupil (pupils accommodate but do not react to light) as the classic hallmark of neurosyphilis associated with this condition.
content.takeAway: Tabes Dorsalis specifically targets the dorsal roots and [[e7f5cbbe|Dorsal Columns]], disrupting the sensory limb of the stretch reflex arc (causing areflexia) and proprioceptive input (causing sensory ataxia and a positive Romberg sign).

content.definition: Glioblastoma (formerly Glioblastoma Multiforme) is the most common and most aggressive primary malignant brain tumor in adults, arising from [[8192f595|Astrocytes]] and characterized by rapid growth, central necrosis, and the ability to cross the corpus callosum.
content.atAGlance:
• Histology: "Pseudopalisading" tumor cells bordering central areas of necrosis and hemorrhage.
  • Imaging: Ring-enhancing lesion on MRI; often crosses the corpus callosum ("Butterfly glioma").
  • Markers: Stains positive for [[fb50d450|GFAP]] (Glial Fibrillary Acidic Protein).
  • Prognosis: Very poor (median survival ~1 year).
  • USMLE Tip: Differentiate from brain abscess (also ring-enhancing) by looking for the butterfly distribution and histologic description of pseudopalisading cells.
content.takeAway: The defining histologic feature of Glioblastoma is pseudopalisading necrosis, where tumor cells crowd around edges of necrotic tissue, combined with microvascular proliferation and a tendency to cross the midline via the corpus callosum.

content.definition: Multiple Sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disorder of the central nervous system characterized by the destruction of [[a24f9747|Oligodendrocytes]] and myelin sheaths, leading to neurological deficits separated in space and time.
content.atAGlance:
• Classic Triad (Charcot): Scanning speech, Intention tremor, and Nystagmus (SIN).
  • Key Findings: [[58c684bd|Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia]] (MLF lesion), Optic Neuritis (painful vision loss), Lhermitte sign (shock sensation on neck flexion).
  • Diagnosis: MRI shows [[d9286430|Periventricular plaques]]; CSF shows increased IgG and Oligoclonal bands.
  • Treatment: Acute flares: IV Steroids. Disease modifying: [[00e48ea3|Beta-interferon]], [[88fffc48|Glatiramer]], [[ae20a0ce|Natalizumab]].
  • USMLE Tip: Bilateral Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO) in a young female is pathognomonic for MS.
content.takeAway: The relapsing-remitting nature of Multiple Sclerosis occurs because the CNS attempts to remyelinate damaged axons (using oligodendrocytes), but repeated autoimmune attacks eventually lead to permanent axonal loss and gliosis (plaques).
